moves.1. e4 c6: The Caro-Kann is my favourite defense to the king-pawn opening.
moves.3... Bf5 4. Nf3: Not 4. Bd3 Bxd3 5. Qxd3 Qb6! 6. Nf3 Qa6 and Black gets a good game. This plan for Black was Nimzovich's idea.
moves.4... h6 5. Be2: The Short variation, championed my English grandmaster Nigel Short.
moves.5... e6 6. O-O Be7 7. c4 Bg5: ?! dubious, sacrificing the "minor exchange" - bishop for knight
moves.11. exf6 gxf6 12. Qe3+ Kf7: The black king is safe on f7 for the moment.
moves.14. Qg3 Qxg3 15. fxg3: Now White has active play on the f-file.
moves.15... Kg6: Moving the King to the g-file, where White's doubled pawns provide shelter
moves.16. g4 Bd7 17. Bd3+ Kg7 18. h3: Black's backward f-pawn has become a target.
moves.19... Nc7 20. Bf5: Perhaps I should have kept the bishops on the board, since Black's bishop is pretty bad compared to White's light-square bishop.
moves.25. Raf1 Nh4 26. Rf3f2 Ne8 27. Ne2 Nd6 2: Black has e4 under control at the moment.
moves.33... b6 34. a4 c5: Black forgot about the pin, but this doesn't cost him any material. Eventually, this costs him the game.
moves.35. dxc5 bxc5 36. Bxc5 Nxc5 37. Re2xe6 N: White's rook is much better placed than Black's.
moves.38... Rh7 39. Rd6 Rb7: The b-pawn is a goner and so is the d-pawn.
moves.40. Rxd5 Rxb2 41. Ra5 Rb7: Now White has a winning endgame.
moves.42. Kf2 Kf7 43. Ra6: Prevents Ke6. Now White can march his king to f5.
Black resigns. Well, it took 50 moves to crack the Caro-Kann, so it's a solid defence indeed.
